name: Hemoglobin
normalRange: 13.8 to 17.2 g/dL for men, 12.1 to 15.1 g/dL for women
importance: Essential for oxygen transport in the blood

name: White Blood Cell Count (WBC)
importance: Indicates immune system activity

name: Platelet Count
importance: Essential for blood clotting

name: Hematocrit
normalRange: 38.8 to 50.0% for men, 34.9 to 44.5% for women
importance: Measures the proportion of red blood cells in the blood

name: Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)
importance: Indicates kidney function

name: Creatinine
normalRange: 0.84 to 1.21 mg/dL for men, 0.56 to 1.00 mg/dL for women
importance: Indicates kidney function

name: Glucose
importance: Primary energy source for the body's cells

name: Calcium
importance: Important for bones and teeth, nerve function, muscle contraction, and blood clotting

name: Sodium
importance: Essential for maintaining fluid balance, muscle function, and nerve function

name: Potassium
importance: Critical for heart function and plays a key role in skeletal and smooth muscle contraction

name: Cholesterol (Total)
importance: Important component of cell membranes and precursor of steroid hormones and vitamin D

name: LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) Cholesterol
importance: Known as 'bad cholesterol'; high levels can lead to plaque formation in arteries

name: HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) Cholesterol
importance: Known as 'good cholesterol'; helps remove LDL cholesterol

name: Triglycerides
importance: Type of fat in the blood; high levels can increase the risk of heart disease

name: Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)
importance: Enzyme found mainly in the liver; high levels can indicate liver damage

name: Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST)
importance: Enzyme found in various tissues but most notably in the liver and heart; used to detect liver damage

name: Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
importance: Enzyme related to the bile ducts; often increased if ducts are blocked

name: Albumin
importance: Protein made by the liver; a measure of nutritional status and liver and kidney function

name: Total Protein
importance: Measures albumin and all other proteins in blood; important for assessing liver and kidney function

name: Bilirubin
importance: Product of the breakdown of red blood cells; can indicate liver problems or anemia

name: Uric Acid
normalRange: 3.5 to 7.2 mg/dL for men, 2.6 to 6.0 mg/dL for women
importance: Waste product removed by the kidneys; high levels can lead to gout or kidney stones

name: C-Reactive Protein (CRP)
importance: Marker of inflammation; can be used to help evaluate risk of cardiovascular disease

name: Prothrombin Time (PT)
importance: Measures how long it takes blood to clot; important for people taking blood thinners

name: Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT)
importance: Used to evaluate the blood's ability to clot; often used to monitor blood-thinning medicines

name: Magnesium
importance: Critical for muscle function, nerve function, blood glucose control, and blood pressure regulation

name: Phosphorus
importance: Important for bone formation, energy storage and release, and urinary pH buffering

name: Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)
importance: Enzyme found in almost all body tissues; high levels can indicate tissue damage

name: Cortisol
normalRange: 10 to 20 mcg/dL in the morning, 3 to 10 mcg/dL in the afternoon
importance: Steroid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex; involved in stress response, blood glucose regulation, and immune function

name: Amylase
importance: Enzyme that helps digest carbohydrates; elevated levels can indicate pancreatitis

name: Lipase
importance: Enzyme that helps digest fats; can be used to help diagnose pancreatitis and other pancreatic diseases

name: Vitamin D
importance: Essential for bone health and immune function; deficiencies can lead to a variety of health problems

name: Folate (Folic Acid)
importance: B vitamin important for cell replication and growth; essential for red blood cell formation and function

name: Vitamin B12
importance: Necessary for red blood cell formation, neurological function, and DNA synthesis

name: Testosterone
normalRange: 300 to 1,000 ng/dL for men, 15 to 70 ng/dL for women
importance: Primary male sex hormone; important for bone density, muscle strength, and the development of male sex characteristics

name: Estradiol
normalRange: 14 to 35 pg/mL for men, 30 to 400 pg/mL for women depending on the menstrual cycle phase
importance: Primary female sex hormone; plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of female reproductive tissues

name: Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA)
importance: Protein produced by the prostate gland; elevated levels can be a sign of prostate cancer

name: Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH)
importance: Regulates thyroid gland function; essential for controlling metabolism, energy generation, and mood

name: Free T4 (Thyroxine)
importance: Thyroid hormone; essential for regulating metabolism, mood, and body temperature

name: Free T3 (Triiodothyronine)
importance: Active thyroid hormone; regulates metabolic rate, heart and digestive function, muscle control, brain development, and bone maintenance

name: Rheumatoid Factor (RF)
importance: Autoantibodies found in rheumatoid arthritis; used in the diagnosis of rheumatic diseases

name: Anti-Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide Antibody (Anti-CCP)
importance: Marker of rheumatoid arthritis; more specific than rheumatoid factor for diagnosing the disease

name: Antinuclear Antibodies (ANA)
importance: Used to diagnose autoimmune diseases, such as lupus and scleroderma

name: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)
normalRange: 0 to 22 mm/hr for men, 0 to 29 mm/hr for women
importance: Non-specific measure of inflammation

name: C-reactive Protein (CRP)
importance: Another non-specific marker used to assess levels of inflammation in the body

name: Iron
importance: Essential for the formation of red blood cells and transportation of oxygen throughout the body

name: Ferritin
normalRange: 20 to 250 ng/mL for men, 10 to 120 ng/mL for women
importance: Indicates the amount of iron stored in the body; used to diagnose iron deficiency or iron overload

name: Transferrin Saturation
importance: Measures the percentage of transferrin that is saturated with iron; used to assess iron status

name: Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)
importance: Indicates how well the body can transport iron in the blood

name: HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin)
importance: Long-term indicator of blood glucose control; used in the diagnosis and monitoring of diabetes

name: D-dimer
importance: Used to help rule out the presence of an inappropriate blood clot (thrombus)
